basics.name: Kristina Gagalova
basics.label: Bioinformatics Scientist
basics.summary: Bioinformatics researcher developing genomics methods for data-driven discovery

work.name: Centre for Crop and Disease Management, Curtin University
work.summary: I develop bioinformatics methods to study plant-pathogen interactions and genome variability using pangenomics, protein structures and high-performance computing

volunteer.summary: Promote Nextflow and nf-core, mentor and support students and developers in Nextflow.

education.institution: University of British Columbia - Genome Sciences Centre
education.area: Algorithms for genome annotations and comparative genomics in complex genomes

awards.title: FindAMasters fellowship
awards.summary: Awarded by FindAMasters in recognition of exceptional academic performance, active engagement within the postgraduate community, and a positive influence on peers.

awards.title: VU Fellowship Programme
awards.summary: A competitive merit-based award covering tuition fees for outstanding students

publications.name: Spruce giga‐genomes: structurally similar yet distinctive with differentially expanding gene families and rapidly evolving genes
publications.summary: Spruce Giga-genomes comparative genomics and genome annotation

publications.name: Leaf pigmentation in Cannabis sativa: Characterization of anthocyanin biosynthesis in colorful Cannabis varieties
publications.summary: Characterization of pigmentation genes in cannabis

projects.name: Plant pangenomics
projects.summary: Developing computational methods to construct and analyze graph-based representations of pangenomes, enabling more accurate modelling of genomic variation across populations and improving downstream analyses like variant calling, functional annotation, and comparative genomics

projects.name: Structural bioinformatics for pathogenicity characterization
projects.summary: Using computational models to predict and analyze protein structures and their interactions, aiding in the understanding of molecular function, binding mechanisms, and potential targets for disease development in crops.
